name: Dog Breeds in the Working Group Online Quiz | Animals | 10 Questions

questions.text: This huge but amiable Canadian breed is used for water rescue.
questions.explanation:
Newfoundland.

	Newfoundlands live to swim- and drool, and shed! Well-bred ones are amazingly sweet and friendly dogs.

questions.text: This was once one of the rarest breeds in the world. In olden days, it helped deliver messages between boats and hauled in fishing gear.
questions.explanation:
Portuguese Water Dog.

	These medium-sized dogs are often mistaken for poodles.

questions.text: Under AKC breed standards, in which of the following dogs is blue eyes an acceptable color?
questions.explanation:
Siberian Husky.

	It's one way of telling the two breeds apart- if it has blue eyes, it's a Siberian.

questions.text: This big and beautiful dog, originally a cattle drover, is tricolor- brown, white and black.
questions.explanation:
Bernese Mountain Dog.

	These dogs have a fairly long coat. Another similar dog, the Greater Swiss Mountain Dog, has a short coat. There are other, smaller similar breeds as well. All are from Switzerland.

questions.text: This breed originated in Germany and was bred as a cross between the bullmastiff and bulldog.
questions.explanation:
Boxer.

	The name might be related to the way the boxer rears up and hits other dogs with its paws, or be a corruption of the German name.

questions.text: This dog is officially classified as a Japanese national treasure.
This breed was created as a protection dog by a German tax collector.
questions.explanation:
Doberman pinscher.

	Louis Dobermann crossed many breeds to obtain his ideal dog.

questions.text: This dog may have once been a cattle driver in Roman times. In Germany, it herded and guarded cattle on their way to market, then protected the master's money on the way home.
This breed, known for rescue work, was originally bred in Trappist monasteries.
questions.explanation:
Saint Bernard.

	However, the brandy kegs are an urban legend!

questions.text: This giant breed comes in many colors, including the black-and-white Harlequin variety.
